items.title: Henderson–Hasselbalch Equation
items.description: Relates pH, pKa and the conjugate base/acid ratio for buffers.
keyPoints: Used to design and analyze buffers

items.title: Gibbs Free Energy
items.description: Predicts reaction spontaneity and links to equilibrium.

items.title: Electronegativity & Periodic Trends
items.description: Trends that determine bonding and reactivity across the periodic table.
keyPoints: Electronegativity & IE increase left→right; atomic radius decreases left→right

items.title: Equilibrium Constant
items.description: Relationship of product and reactant concentrations at equilibrium.
keyPoints: Relates to ΔG° and reaction position

items.title: Atomic Structure & Periodic Trends
items.description: Electron configurations and the properties they drive.

items.title: Acid–Base Chemistry
items.description: pH, pKa, buffers and titration essentials for biological systems.

items.title: Redox Reactions
items.description: Electron transfer processes and their role in metabolism.
keyPoints: Redox couples and standard reduction potentials

items.title: Stoichiometry & Limiting Reagents
items.description: Quantitative relationships in chemical reactions for yield calculations.
keyPoints: Identify limiting reagent to calculate theoretical yield

items.title: Gas Laws
items.description: Relationships between pressure, volume, temperature and moles of gas.
keyPoints: Combined gas law for changing conditions

items.title: Solutions & Concentrations
items.description: Calculating molarity, molality and preparing solutions.

items.title: Thermochemistry
items.description: Enthalpy, entropy and their role in reaction energetics.
keyPoints: ΔH = heat change at constant pressure

items.title: Functional Groups & Reactivity
items.description: Key functional groups and their chemical behavior.

items.title: Stereochemistry
items.description: Chirality, enantiomers, diastereomers and their biological implications.

items.title: Reaction Mechanisms
items.description: Common organic reaction types and their stepwise mechanisms.

items.title: Aromaticity & Hückel's Rule
items.description: Aromatic compounds and their stability and reactivity.

items.title: Glycolysis
items.description: 10-step pathway converting glucose to pyruvate with ATP and NADH generation.
keyPoints: Pyruvate fate: TCA, lactate, or gluconeogenesis

items.title: Citric Acid Cycle (TCA)
items.description: Central metabolic hub oxidizing acetyl-CoA and generating reducing equivalents.

items.title: Michaelis–Menten Kinetics
items.description: Enzyme kinetics model linking reaction rate to substrate concentration.

items.title: Electron Transport Chain & Oxidative Phosphorylation
items.description: Electron transfer through complexes I–IV and ATP synthesis.
keyPoints: P/O ratio ~2.5 for NADH, ~1.5 for FADH2

items.title: Metabolic Regulation & Allosteric Control
items.description: Feedback inhibition and allosteric enzyme modulation.
keyPoints: Allosteric sites remote from active site

items.title: Signal Transduction Pathways
items.description: Cell communication via receptors, kinase cascades and second messengers.

items.title: Translation & Protein Synthesis
items.description: mRNA → protein: codons, tRNA, ribosome and post-translational modifications.

items.title: Protein Folding & Chaperones
items.description: Thermodynamic and kinetic aspects of protein structure formation.

items.title: Gene Regulation
items.description: Transcriptional and translational control of gene expression.

items.title: Protein Purification & Analysis
items.description: Techniques to isolate and characterize proteins from cells.

items.title: Enzyme Assays & Kinetics
items.description: Measuring enzyme activity and determining kinetic parameters.

items.title: SDS-PAGE & Gel Electrophoresis
items.description: Separating proteins by size and analyzing protein composition.

items.title: DNA/RNA Techniques (PCR, qPCR, Sequencing)
items.description: Amplifying, quantifying and sequencing nucleic acids.

items.title: DNA & RNA Structure
items.description: Double helix, base pairing, and structural variations.

items.title: DNA Replication
items.description: Semi-conservative replication machinery and fidelity.

items.title: Transcription
items.description: DNA → RNA: promoters, polymerase, capping and splicing.
keyPoints: RNA Pol II in eukaryotes, Pol I/III roles

items.title: Recombinant DNA Technology
items.description: Restriction enzymes, cloning and genetic manipulation.

items.description: Modern gene editing with Cas9 and related endonucleases.

items.title: Cell Structure & Function
items.description: Organelles, membranes and compartmentalization in eukaryotes.

items.title: Bioenergetics & Membranes
items.description: Energy flow and membrane biology in living systems.

items.title: Bacterial Structure & Physiology
items.description: Cell wall, pili, flagella, plasmids and metabolic modes.

items.title: Viruses & Replication Cycles
items.description: Viral structure, entry, replication and lysis strategies.

items.title: Antibiotics & Resistance Mechanisms
items.description: Mechanisms of action and bacterial resistance strategies.

items.title: Quantum Chemistry Basics
items.description: Schrödinger equation and orbital concepts for molecular structure.

items.title: Advanced Thermodynamics
items.description: Phase diagrams, activity coefficients, and chemical potential.

items.title: Chemical Kinetics & Rate Laws
items.description: Reaction mechanisms, rate constants and temperature dependence.

items.title: Classical Mechanics
items.description: Motion, forces and conservation laws needed for problem solving.

items.title: Waves & Oscillations
items.description: Wave behavior and basic modal analysis.

items.title: Thermal Physics / Thermodynamics
items.description: Laws of thermodynamics, heat transfer and state functions.

items.title: Circuits
items.description: Basic circuit analysis and component behavior.

items.title: Diagrams (Free-body / Energy / Circuit)
items.description: Visual tools essential for solving physics problems.

items.title: Lenses
items.description: Optics basics and lens equation for image formation.

items.title: Fluids
items.description: Fluid statics and dynamics principles for biological contexts.

items.title: Electricity & Magnetism
items.description: Electrostatics, circuits and magnetic fields relevant to biophysics.

items.title: Modern Physics
items.description: Quantum mechanics and relativity basics for understanding atomic and subatomic phenomena.
keyPoints: Special relativity time dilation & length contraction

items.title: Statics & Dynamics
items.description: Equilibrium conditions and motion analysis for biological systems.

items.title: Distributions
items.description: Choose and interpret probability distributions for experimental data.

items.title: Descriptive Statistics
items.description: Summarize biological data and communicate variability.
keyPoints: Report n and units; plot individual points

items.title: Biological vs Technical Replicates
items.description: Designing replicates correctly to separate true biological variation from measurement error.

items.title: Hypothesis Testing
items.description: Framework to decide if observed differences are likely real.

items.title: t-Tests & ANOVA
items.description: Comparing means between two or more groups with appropriate assumptions.

items.title: Regression & Enzyme Kinetics
items.description: Curve fitting for calibration and nonlinear kinetics (Michaelis–Menten).

items.title: Error Analysis & Confidence Intervals
items.description: Quantify uncertainty and combine errors through calculations.

items.title: Sampling & Power
items.description: Plan sample sizes to detect effects reliably.
keyPoints: Effect size and sample size tradeoffs

items.title: Derivatives
items.description: Rates of change and slopes of functions for modeling biological processes.

items.title: Integrals
items.description: Area under curves and accumulation functions in biology.

items.title: Differential Equations
items.description: Modeling dynamic systems like population growth or enzyme kinetics.

items.title: Multivariable Calculus
items.description: Functions of multiple variables and partial derivatives for complex biological systems.
keyPoints: Multiple integrals for volume and probability

items.title: Limits
items.description: Understanding behavior of functions as inputs approach specific values, important for continuity and defining derivatives.
keyPoints: Limits at infinity and asymptotic behavior

items.title: Titration
items.description: Methods and calculations for acid–base and redox titrations.

items.title: Spectroscopy (IR, NMR, UV-Vis)
items.description: Techniques for molecular identification and quantification.

items.title: Dilutions & Molarity
items.description: Accurate concentration preparation for lab work.

items.title: Extraction & Purification
items.description: Techniques for isolating and purifying organic compounds.

items.title: Synthesis & Retrosynthesis
items.description: Planning and executing multi-step organic syntheses.

items.title: Green Chemistry Principles
items.description: Sustainable practices in organic synthesis and lab work.

items.title: Calibration & Standard Curves
items.description: Preparing and using standard curves for quantification.

items.title: Chromatography (HPLC, GC)
items.description: Separation techniques for compound analysis.

items.title: Mass Spectrometry
items.description: Ionization, separation and detection of molecular masses.

items.title: Error Propagation & Detection Limits
items.description: Quantifying measurement uncertainty and instrumental limits.

items.title: Coordination Compounds & Complexes
items.description: Ligand types, coordination geometry and stereoisomerism.

items.title: Crystal Field Theory
items.description: Splitting of d orbitals and color in transition metal complexes.

items.title: Transition Metals & Variable Oxidation States
items.description: Properties and reactivity of transition elements.

items.title: Organometallics & Catalysis
items.description: Metal-carbon bonds and their role in catalysis.

items.title: Derivatives & Rates of Change
items.description: Using derivatives to model reaction rates and optimization.
keyPoints: Power rule, product rule, chain rule

items.title: Integrals & Accumulation
items.description: Integration for area under curves and cumulative effects.

items.title: Differential Equations
items.description: Modeling dynamic systems: population growth, kinetics, diffusion.

items.title: Partial Derivatives & Multivariable Functions
items.description: Calculus for functions of multiple variables.

items.title: Acid–Base Titration
items.description: Quantitative analysis using endpoint determination.
keyPoints: Choice of indicator based on pH range

items.title: Spectroscopy (IR, NMR, UV-Vis)
items.description: Molecular structure elucidation and quantification.

items.title: Solutions & Dilutions
items.description: Making and diluting solutions of precise concentration.

items.title: Lab Safety & Data Recording
items.description: Essential practices for safe and reproducible work.
keyPoints: Proper lab notebook documentation & significant figures

items.title: BLAST & Sequence Alignment
items.description: Finding similar sequences in databases and understanding homology searches.

items.title: Molecular Databases
items.description: Key resources for accessing sequence and structure data.
keyPoints: UniProt for protein sequences and annotations

items.title: Multiple Sequence Alignment & Phylogenetics
items.description: Comparing multiple sequences and inferring evolutionary relationships.

items.title: Protein Structure Prediction
items.description: Predicting 3D fold from amino acid sequence using computational methods.

items.title: DNA Structure & Replication
items.description: DNA double helix and semi-conservative replication mechanisms.

items.title: Transcription & Translation
items.description: From DNA to mRNA to protein: the central dogma of molecular biology.
keyPoints: Genetic code and translation machinery (ribosomes, tRNA)

items.title: Molecular Techniques (PCR, Sequencing, Cloning)
items.description: Essential lab methods for manipulating and analyzing DNA.

items.title: Epigenetics
items.description: Heritable changes in gene expression without DNA sequence changes.

items.title: Glycolysis
items.description: 10-step pathway converting glucose → pyruvate; central entry point to carbohydrate metabolism.
keyPoints: Net 2 ATP, 2 NADH per glucose (anaerobic → lactate regenerates NAD⁺)
Key regulatory enzymes: hexokinase/glucokinase, PFK-1 (major control), pyruvate kinase
Important branch points: G6P → PPP, F6P ↔ F2,6BP regulation

items.title: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase (PDH) Complex
items.description: Links glycolysis to the TCA by converting pyruvate → acetyl-CoA; a major control point.
keyPoints: Cofactors: TPP, lipoate, FAD, NAD⁺, CoA (TLC FN)
Inhibited by high ATP, NADH, acetyl-CoA; activated by ADP, Ca²⁺ (tissue-specific)
Block → pyruvate→lactate buildup (lactic acidosis) and reduced TCA flux

items.title: Citric Acid Cycle (TCA / Krebs)
items.description: Oxidizes acetyl-CoA to CO₂ while producing reducing equivalents for the ETC.
keyPoints: Per acetyl-CoA: 3 NADH, 1 FADH₂, 1 GTP (or ATP)
Regulatory enzymes: citrate synthase, isocitrate dehydrogenase, α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Anaplerotic reactions (e.g., pyruvate → oxaloacetate) maintain intermediate pools

items.title: ETC & Oxidative Phosphorylation
items.description: Complexes I–IV transfer electrons, pump protons, and drive ATP synthesis via ATP synthase.
keyPoints: Complexes I–IV & ATP synthase: proton motive force (Δψ + ΔpH) drives ATP production
Approximate P/O: ~2.5 ATP/NADH, ~1.5 ATP/FADH₂ (use for rough energy accounting)
Uncouplers collapse gradient → heat; inhibitors block electron flow (clinical/toxicology relevance)

items.title: Gluconeogenesis
items.description: Pathway creating glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors; circumvents irreversible glycolysis steps.
keyPoints: Key bypass enzymes: pyruvate carboxylase, PEP carboxykinase, fructose-1,6-bisphosphatase, glucose-6-phosphatase
Reciprocal regulation with glycolysis (F2,6BP central regulator)
Major substrates: lactate, alanine, glycerol, TCA intermediates

items.title: Glycogen Synthesis & Breakdown
items.description: Storage and rapid mobilization of glucose; hormonally controlled.
keyPoints: Glycogen synthase = synthesis (activated by insulin); glycogen phosphorylase = breakdown (activated by glucagon/epinephrine)
Branching enzyme and debranching enzyme are essential for structure and mobilization
Clinical ties: glycogen storage diseases alter blood glucose and muscle energy

items.title: Pentose Phosphate Pathway (PPP)
items.description: Generates NADPH for biosynthesis/antioxidant defense and ribose-5-phosphate for nucleotide synthesis.
keyPoints: Rate-limiting enzyme: G6PD (clinical relevance: G6PD deficiency → hemolysis)
NADPH used for fatty acid synthesis, glutathione reduction, detoxification
Non-oxidative branch provides ribose or feeds back into glycolysis

items.title: Fatty Acid Oxidation & Synthesis
items.description: β-oxidation (mitochondria) catabolizes fatty acids to acetyl-CoA; synthesis (cytosol) builds fatty acids from acetyl-CoA.
keyPoints: β-oxidation uses carnitine shuttle for long-chain FA entry into mitochondria
Products: acetyl-CoA, NADH, FADH₂ (feed into TCA/ETC)
ACC (acetyl-CoA carboxylase) is rate-limiting for FA synthesis; regulated by citrate, AMPK, insulin

items.title: Ketogenesis
items.description: Liver generates ketone bodies from acetyl-CoA during prolonged fasting or low insulin states.
keyPoints: Primary ketones: acetoacetate, β-hydroxybutyrate (transportable fuels for brain/heart)
Occurs when acetyl-CoA accumulates and TCA capacity is limited (low OAA)
Clinical: diabetic ketoacidosis — high ketones + metabolic acidosis

items.title: Urea Cycle & Nitrogen Disposal
items.description: Removes excess nitrogen by converting ammonia → urea (primarily in liver).
keyPoints: Key enzymes: carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS I), ornithine transcarbamylase
Interconnects with TCA via fumarate; defects cause hyperammonemia
Clinically relevant: urea cycle disorders present with neurologic symptoms from ammonia toxicity

criticalReview.sectionTitle: MCAT Prep — High-Yield Metabolism Concepts & Strategy

items.title: Regulation & Hormonal Control
items.description: How hormones and allosteric signals shift metabolic flux: insulin vs glucagon/epinephrine, energy charge signaling.
keyPoints: Insulin generally promotes storage (glycogen, FA synthesis); glucagon/epinephrine promote mobilization (glycogenolysis, gluconeogenesis, lipolysis)
Allosteric regulators: ATP/AMP, citrate, F2,6BP; Ca²⁺ activates PDH/kinases in muscle
Exam focus: predict directional change when a regulator or hormone changes

items.title: Cellular Compartments & Pathway Locations
items.description: Where pathways occur matters: cytosol vs mitochondria vs peroxisome vs ER.
keyPoints: Glycolysis & PPP: cytosol; TCA & β-oxidation: mitochondria; FA synthesis: cytosol/ER; peroxisomes: very-long chain FA oxidation
Shuttles (e.g., malate–aspartate, glycerol-3-phosphate) move reducing equivalents across membranes
MCAT likes questions linking location to mechanism or pathology

items.title: Energy Accounting & Redox Roles
items.description: Practical ATP estimation and roles of NADH vs NADPH in catabolism vs anabolism/antioxidant defense.
keyPoints: Be able to approximate ATP yield from glucose (glycolysis + PDH + TCA + ETC)
NADH → ATP via ETC; NADPH used for biosynthesis and glutathione regeneration
Recognize oxidized vs reduced forms and consequences of redox imbalance

items.title: Pathway Integration & Physiologic States
items.description: How metabolism shifts during fed, fasting, exercise, and starvation states.
keyPoints: Fed: insulin ↑ → glycolysis, glycogen & FA synthesis; Fasting: glucagon ↑ → gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, ketogenesis
Exercise: muscle increases glycolysis, PDH activation via Ca²⁺/AMP
Practice mapping flux changes for given hormonal or substrate changes

items.title: Clinical & Deficiency Implications
items.description: Common metabolic defects and their biochemical consequences (high-yield for MCAT).
keyPoints: Examples: PDH deficiency → lactic acidosis; G6PD deficiency → hemolysis with oxidative stress
Glycogen storage diseases cause hypoglycemia or myopathy depending on enzyme/location
MCAT may ask mechanistic reasons for clinical phenotypes

items.title: Graphs, Experiments & Kinetics
items.description: How to read rate curves, enzyme kinetics, and interpret experimental manipulations.
keyPoints: Be comfortable with Michaelis–Menten basics and how Vmax/Km change with inhibitors
Interpreting metabolic flux from labeling experiments or enzyme activity assays is common
Practice passage-style questions that require data interpretation

items.title: Acid–Base & Buffering Relevance
items.description: Metabolism affects blood pH (e.g., lactic acid, ketoacids); know buffer systems and clinical consequences.
keyPoints: Lactic acidosis from anaerobic glycolysis/exercise or PDH block
Ketone production in prolonged fasting or uncontrolled diabetes → metabolic acidosis
MCAT may couple metabolic flux to pH changes and physiological compensation

items.title: Mnemonics & High-Yield Study Actions
items.description: Concise study tactics and memory aids to prepare efficiently.
keyPoints: Mnemonics: 'Citrate Is Kreb’s Starting Substrate For Making Oxaloacetate' for TCA order; 'TLC FN' for PDH cofactors
Study actions: draw cycles from memory, active recall flashcards (enzymes/locations/regulators), timed passage practice
Practice ~6–8 AAMC-style passages weekly and make a one-page cheat sheet of net yields & regulation
